name: German Shepherd
metaDescription: German Shepherds are prone to hip dysplasia and degenerative myelopathy. Compare the best pet insurance for GSDs—coverage, costs, and top picks.
intro: German Shepherds are intelligent, loyal, and unfortunately prone to expensive orthopedic and neurological conditions. Hip dysplasia affects nearly 20% of the breed, and degenerative myelopathy has no cure—only management. Here's how to find coverage that protects your GSD.
whyInsurance: German Shepherds are the 4th most popular breed in America—and among the most expensive to treat when things go wrong. Their sloped backs and active lifestyles create a perfect storm for joint and spine issues.

topPicks.name: Embrace
topPicks.highlight: Best for orthopedic coverage (6-month waiting period)

topPicks.name: Trupanion
topPicks.highlight: Best for ongoing conditions (pays vet directly)

mustHave: Orthopedic conditions – Hip and elbow dysplasia are near-guaranteed
Emergency surgery – Bloat requires immediate, expensive intervention
Chronic condition coverage – DM, EPI, allergies need ongoing care
High annual limits – $20k minimum; unlimited preferred
redFlags: Orthopedic exclusions or bilateral condition exclusions
12-14 month orthopedic waiting periods if your GSD is already 1+

providers.name: Embrace
providers.description: Embrace's 6-month orthopedic waiting period beats the 12-14 months most competitors require. They also cover bilateral conditions without exclusions—if one hip fails, the other is still covered.
pros: Diminishing deductible saves money over time

providers.name: Trupanion
providers.description: Trupanion's model is different: 90% reimbursement, no annual limits, and they pay vets directly at checkout. For GSDs facing chronic conditions like DM or EPI, this removes ongoing claim hassle.
pros: One deductible per condition, per lifetime

providers.name: Figo
providers.description: Figo offers up to $100,000 annual limits or unlimited coverage—important for large breeds with expensive surgeries. Their app-based experience is also one of the best.

costIntro: German Shepherds are large dogs with documented health issues—expect premiums on the higher side.

faqs.question: Is pet insurance worth it for German Shepherds?
faqs.answer: Yes. With nearly 1 in 5 GSDs developing hip dysplasia and bloat being a life-threatening emergency, major vet bills are common. Insurance protects against the $5,000-10,000+ surgeries this breed often needs.

faqs.question: Does pet insurance cover hip dysplasia in German Shepherds?
faqs.answer: Yes—all major providers cover hip dysplasia as a hereditary condition. However, most require a 6-12 month waiting period, so enroll early before symptoms appear.

faqs.question: What is degenerative myelopathy, and is it covered?
faqs.answer: DM is a progressive spinal cord disease common in German Shepherds. It's covered by pet insurance as a chronic illness, including diagnostics, medications, mobility aids, and physical therapy.

faqs.question: Should I get insurance for a German Shepherd puppy?
faqs.answer: Absolutely. Puppies have the lowest premiums, no pre-existing conditions, and you'll clear orthopedic waiting periods before issues typically develop (around age 1-2).

faqs.question: What's the orthopedic waiting period for German Shepherds?
faqs.answer: Most insurers require 6-14 months before covering orthopedic conditions like hip dysplasia. Embrace offers the shortest at 6 months. Enroll early to clear this window.

finalCta: German Shepherds give everything to their families. Give them the protection they deserve.
